sols_html:
Let \(A(q)\) denote the average cost per kilogram of producing \(q\) kilograms of this chemical,

\[\begin{aligned} A(q) = \frac{C(q)}{q} = 3q^{1/3}+50+\frac{10000}{q}.\end{aligned}\]

The domain of interest is \((0,\infty)\) because the company cannot produce negative kilograms of their product. In order to find the absolute minimum of the average cost function, we begin by looking for its critical points. The derivative of \(A\) is

\[\begin{aligned} A'(q) = q^{-2/3}-\frac{10000}{q^2} = \frac{1}{q^2} (q^{4/3}-10000)\end{aligned}\]

This exists everywhere in our domain and is equal to zero when \(q^{4/3}-10000 =0\), that is, when

\[\begin{aligned} q^{\frac43}=10000 = 10^4.\end{aligned}\]

Since \(q\geq 0\), we can take the positive fourth root of both sides to obtain

\[\begin{aligned} q^{\frac13}=10.\end{aligned}\]

Hence,

\[\begin{aligned} q=10^3 = 1000\end{aligned}\]

which is our final answer.

Note:

It is easy to check that this is indeed an absolute minimum by noting that \(A'(q)<0\) when \(q<1000\) and \(A'(q)>0\) when \(q>1000\). Since \(A(q)\) is decreasing when \(q<1000\) and increasing when \(q>1000\), \(A(q)\) must have an absolute minimum at \(q=1000.\)

Hence, the company should produce 1000 kg of chemical in order to minimize its average cost.

statement_html:
It costs a small firm C(q) dollars to produce q kilograms of a certain chemical, where

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}C(q)=3q^{4/3}+50q+10000\end{aligned}\]

The average cost of production per kilogram is defined to be

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}\frac{C(q)}{q}.\end{aligned}\]

Use calculus to find how many kilograms the firm should produce in order to minimize the average cost of production per kilogram. Please simplify. You need not justify that your calculation actually minimizes average cost.
